instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook won’t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message:
Good day friends, so I have here this MacBook which is drawing 20V 180mA only the Mainboard and 1,4A with battery. No Apple logo no boot. Here are some voltages:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,70V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3,30V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 19,7V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5,1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 5,1V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 5,1
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3,3 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 3,3 V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> = 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 1,8V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 1,5V

I found out that <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> = 0V / 10,5ohms. Checked this with a 2017er MacBook resistance is same but 0,635V. So I have checked:

VCIN of <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7230</CHIP> = 5,10V
VIN of <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7230</CHIP> = 8,70V

<SIGNAL>ZCD_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V = <SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>CPUCORE_FCCM</SIGNAL> is produced by <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

VIN of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> = 8,7V
VCC of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> = 5,1V

I don't see an enable pin for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Schematics says for VIN 12,9V I got 8,7V, maybe this is problem or bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>? Or something else?

cheers

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,70V"
Was that with battery connected?
You should check with charger alone.

Any history fault available?
You can try known good BIOS; just make backup first.

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: "<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8,70V" = without battery only the board alone. Unfortunately there is no history available :( With battery connected around 8,4V

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: Is the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> chip the bios on this board?

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: Look like the bios chip is dead. Pls can you confirm that this is the right direction to solder on the board of the ubos2? Anyway I reballed several times and tried both directions but no reaction of the chip.

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: The marked corner on chip and adapter board seems to correspond in the picture.

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: ok thank you. I will order a new chip and try again

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message:
I have now replaced the SPI Rom, it's not an quick job, because you have to solder and reball after programming. Noticed that there are 2 kinds of chips. Didn't got the original one, but it is possible to turn the chip 90° and it is ok. So now the situation is, that I got no voltages. The only voltage I get is the PPDCIN 5V 3mA. Looks like <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR> or <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> is faulty, but why now? This board is driving me crazy...

<TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>:
Gate 1= 10,80V
Gate 2 = 6,90V

I do not understand why the gate have more voltage that the incoming voltage?

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message:
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip has internal charge pump to control the Gate for N-channel MOSFETs.

Did you solder the chip in the same orientation like it was in MLB?
Did you verify the file after writing?

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: Not possible to solder in same orientation because the chip is little bit different. I have to rotate the chip by 90 degrees. File is double checked

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: Did you compare datasheet of both chips?

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: Schematics says Q64FVBYIQ this chip here is Q64FVYIQ this is looks the same. Also Alixpress sales this as the same. This chip I bought 5pcs was sold as the rom for <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>. What I have tried now is multiple times changed the chip, erased sold again, nothing changed. Also tried power without this chip, same behaviour. I don't how is the behaviour of a mainboard without the rom, but I think it should also without the rom switch to 20V or not?

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message:
If BIOS didn't help, then you have bad CPU.
It fails a lot on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>, as no fan used.

threads.title: MacBook 12" 2016 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not power on
threads.message: I have ordered now a new bios original programmed bios chip. Will also change the <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and the <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>
